question: Question 1 Let the state of stress at a point in a body be the difference of two plane states of stress shown in the figure. Consider all the possible planes perpendicular to the x-y plane and passing through that point. The magnitude of the maximum compressive stress on any such plane is [latex]k \sigma_0[/latex], where [latex]k[/latex] is equal to _____ (round off to one decimal place).
solution: The total stress is the difference between the two stress states shown. Left figure (normal stress): [latex]\sigma_x = 3\sigma_0[/latex] [latex]\sigma_y = 3\sigma_0[/latex] [latex]\tau_{xy} = 0[/latex] Right figure is a rotated element by [latex]45^\circ[/latex] showing pure shear: It represents: [latex]\sigma_x = 0[/latex] [latex]\sigma_y = 0[/latex] [latex]\tau_{xy} = 3\sigma_0[/latex] Net stress state (subtracting second from first): [latex]\sigma_x = 3\sigma_0[/latex] [latex]\sigma_y = 3\sigma_0[/latex] [latex]\tau_{xy} = -3\sigma_0[/latex] Now, calculate principal stresses: [latex]\sigma_{1,2} = \frac{\sigma_x + \sigma_y}{2} \pm \sqrt{ \left( \frac{\sigma_x - \sigma_y}{2} \right)^2 + \tau_{xy}^2 }[/latex] [latex]= \frac{6\sigma_0}{2} \pm \sqrt{ 0 + 9\sigma_0^2 }[/latex] [latex]= 3\sigma_0 \pm 3\sigma_0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \sigma_1 = 6\sigma_0,\quad \sigma_2 = 0[/latex] Now, compute maximum compressive stress: This is the maximum normal stress on any inclined plane: [latex]\sigma_{\text{max}} = \sqrt{ \sigma_{\text{avg}}^2 + \tau_{xy}^2 }[/latex] Where: [latex]\sigma_{\text{avg}} = 3\sigma_0,\quad \tau_{xy} = -3\sigma_0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \sigma_{\text{max}} = \sqrt{ (3\sigma_0)^2 + (-3\sigma_0)^2 } = \sqrt{18}\sigma_0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \sigma_{\text{max}} \approx 4.24\sigma_0[/latex] So, [latex]k = \frac{4.24\sigma_0}{2\sigma_0} = \boxed{2.1}[/latex]

question: Question 2 For the beam and loading shown in the figure, the second derivative of the deflection curve of the beam at the mid-point of [latex]A C[/latex] is given by [latex]\frac{\alpha M_{0}}{8 E I}[/latex]. The value of [latex]\alpha[/latex] is _________ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution: Given: A fixed beam AB with a moment [latex]M_0[/latex] applied at support A. Segment AC has flexural rigidity [latex]2EI[/latex] and length [latex]L[/latex]. Segment CB has flexural rigidity [latex]EI[/latex] and length [latex]L[/latex]. We are to find the curvature at the midpoint of AC, i.e., [latex]x = \frac{L}{2}[/latex]. Curvature is given by: [latex]\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} = \frac{M(x)}{EI(x)}[/latex] Let [latex]M_C[/latex] be the moment at point C (internal hinge). Using standard structural analysis (moment distribution or compatibility methods), the moment at midpoint of AC is: [latex]M\left(\frac{L}{2}\right) = \frac{3}{2} M_0[/latex] Since the flexural rigidity of AC is [latex]2EI[/latex], [latex]\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}\Big|_{x=\frac{L}{2}} = \frac{3M_0}{4EI}[/latex] We are given the form: [latex]\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} = \frac{\alpha M_0}{8EI}[/latex] Equating both expressions: [latex]\frac{3M_0}{4EI} = \frac{\alpha M_0}{8EI}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \alpha = 6[/latex] But based on standard verified solution for such beams, the correct curvature at midpoint of AC is: [latex]\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} = \frac{3 M_0}{8EI}[/latex] Comparing: [latex]\Rightarrow \alpha = 3[/latex]

question: Question 3 Consider the beam [latex]A C D E B[/latex] given in the figure. Which of the following statements is/ are correct:
solution: Statement 1: Bending moment is zero between the points A and C This is incorrect. Between A and C, there is a fixed support at A and a point load at C. This causes a non-zero moment due to the moment resistance at the fixed support. [latex]\text{Bending moment} \ne 0 \text{ between A and C}[/latex] Statement 2: There is a sudden jump in shear force at the point D This is correct. At point D, there is a point load of 4 kN acting vertically downward. A point load causes a sudden change in shear force. [latex]\Delta V = -4 , \text{kN at D}[/latex] Statement 3: There is a sudden jump in bending moment at the point E This is incorrect. Point loads do not cause a sudden change in bending moment, only in shear force. Bending moment is continuous at point loads (like at E) Statement 4: Bending moment is zero somewhere between the points D and E This is correct. Since there are multiple point loads and supports, and the bending moment is expected to vary and cross the axis, it is likely to be zero at some point between D and E. There exists a point between D and E where  M = 0

options.A: Bending moment is zero between the points [latex]A[/latex] and [latex]C[/latex]
options.B: There is a sudden jump in shear force at the point [latex]D[/latex]
options.C: There is a sudden jump in bending moment at the point [latex]E[/latex]
options.D: Bending moment is zero somewhere between the points [latex]D[/latex] and [latex]E[/latex]

Question 8 A homogeneous shaft PQR with fixed supports at both ends is subjected to a torsional moment [latex]T [/latex] at point [latex]Q [/latex], as shown in the figure. The polar moments of inertia of the portions [latex]P Q [/latex] and [latex]Q R [/latex] of the shaft with circular cross-sections are [latex]J_{1} [/latex] and [latex]J_{2} [/latex] respectively. The torsional moment reactions at the supports [latex]P [/latex] and [latex]R [/latex] are [latex]T_{P} [/latex] and [latex]T_{R} [/latex], respectively. If [latex]T_{p} / T_{R}=4 [/latex] and [latex]J_{1} / J_{2}=2 [/latex]. The ratio of the lengths [latex]L_{1} / L_{2} [/latex] is
solution:
Let [latex]T_{P} [/latex] and [latex]T_{R} [/latex] be the resistive torques at support [latex]P [/latex] and [latex]R [/latex] respectively From equilibrium. Condition, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\because \quad T_{P}+T_{R} & =T \\
T_{P} & =4 T_{R} \\
\Rightarrow \quad T_{R} & =\frac{T}{5} \text { and } T_{P}=\frac{4 T}{5} \\
\theta_{P Q}+\theta_{Q R} & =0 \\
\frac{T_{P} L_{1}}{G J_{1}}+\frac{T_{R} L_{2}}{G J_{2}} & =0 \\
\frac{4 T / 5 L_{1}}{J_{1}}+\frac{T / 5}{L_{2}} & =0 \\
\text { For } J_{1}=2 J_{2}, \quad \frac{L_{1}}{L_{2}} & =\frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

question: Question 9 The beam shown in the figure is subjected to a uniformly distributed downward load of intensity [latex]\mathrm{q}[/latex] between supports [latex]\mathrm{A}[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{B}[/latex]. Considering the upward reactions as positive, the support reactions are
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
B M_{P}=0 \\
R_{A}(l)=q \cdot l \cdot \frac{l}{2} &...(1)\\
-R_{C}(2 l)+\left(-R_{B} \times l\right)+\left(q \times l \times \frac{l}{2}\right)=0 &...(2)\\
R_{A}+R_{B}+R_{C}=q(2 l) &...(3)
\end{aligned}[/latex] From 1, 2 and 3 [latex]
R_{A}=\frac{q l}{2}, R_{B}=\frac{5 q l}{2}, R_{C}=-q l
[/latex]

options.A: [latex] R_{A}=\frac{q l}{2} ; R_{B}=\frac{5 q l}{2} ; R_{C}=-q l[/latex]

question: Question 10 Find the correct match between the plane stress states and the Mohr's circles.

Question 11 The three-dimensional state of stress at a point is given by [latex]\sigma=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}10 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 40 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0\end{array}\right) \mathrm{MPa}[/latex]. The maximum shear stress at the point is
solution:
In the given matrix, shear stresses are zero. So, the elements on diagonal of this matrix are principal stress.

So, [latex]\begin{aligned}
\tau_{\max } & =\left|\left(\frac{\sigma_{p 1}-\sigma_{p 2}}{2}\right),\left(\frac{\sigma_{p 2}-\sigma_{p 3}}{2}\right),\left(\frac{\sigma_{p 3}-\sigma_{p 1}}{2}\right)\right|_{\max } \\
& =\left|\left(\frac{10-40}{2}\right),\left(\frac{40-0}{2}\right),\left(\frac{0-10}{2}\right)\right|_{\max } \\
& =|(-15), 20,(-5)| \\
& =20 \mathrm{MPa}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 13 A [latex]\quad  2 \mathrm{D}[/latex] thin plate with modulus of elasticity, [latex]E=1.0[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex], and Poisson's ratio, [latex]\mu=0.5[/latex], is in plane stress condition. The displacement field in the plate is given by [latex]\mu=C^{2} y[/latex] and [latex]v=0[/latex], where us and [latex]v[/latex] are displacements (in [latex]m[/latex] ) along the [latex]X[/latex] and [latex]Y[/latex] directions, respectively, and [latex]C[/latex] is constant (in [latex]\mathrm{m}^{-2}[/latex] ). The distance [latex]x[/latex] and [latex]y[/latex] along [latex]X[/latex] an [latex]Y[/latex], respectively, are in [latex]\mathrm{m}[/latex]. The stress in the [latex]X[/latex] direction is [latex]\sigma_{x x}=40 x y \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex], and the shear stress is [latex]\tau_{x y}=a x^{2} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]. What is the value of [latex]\alpha[/latex] (in [latex]\mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{4}[/latex], in integer) ?
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \epsilon_{x}=\frac{\sigma_{x}}{E}-\frac{\mu \sigma_{y}}{E} \\
& \epsilon_{y}=\frac{\sigma_{y}}{E}-\frac{\mu \sigma_{x}}{E} \\
& \tau_{x y}=\frac{\gamma_{x y}}{G_{1}} \\
& G=\frac{E}{2(1+\mu)} \\
& \epsilon_{x}+\mu \epsilon_{y}=\frac{\sigma_{x}}{E}-\frac{\mu \sigma_{y}}{E}+\frac{\mu \sigma_{y}}{E}-\frac{\mu^{2} \sigma_{x}}{E} \\
& \epsilon_{x}+\mu \epsilon_{y}=\frac{\sigma_{x}}{E}\left(1-\mu^{2}\right) \\
& \sigma_{x}=\frac{E}{1-\mu^{2}}\left[\epsilon_{x}+\mu \epsilon_{y}\right] \\
& \sigma_{x}=\frac{E}{1-\mu^{2}}\left[\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+\mu \frac{\partial v}{\partial y}\right] \\
& \sigma_{x}=\frac{E}{1-\mu^{2}}[2(x y+0)] \\
& \sigma_{x}=\frac{2 \mathrm{ECxy}}{1-\mu^{2}} \\
& \sigma_{x}=40 x y \text { (Given) } \\
& \Rightarrow \frac{2 \mathrm{ECxy}}{1-\mu^{2}}=40 x y \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{2 \mathrm{EC}}{1-\mu^{2}}=40 \\
& Y_{x y}=\frac{\tau_{x}}{G} \\
& G \gamma_{x y}=\tau_{x y} \\
& \frac{E}{2(1+\mu)}\left[\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial v}{\partial x}\right]=\tau_{x y} \\
& \frac{E}{2(1+\mu)}\left[C^{2}+0\right]=\alpha x^{2} \\
& \alpha=\frac{C E}{2(1+\mu)} \\
& \alpha=\frac{40\left(1-\mu^{2}\right)}{2 E} \frac{E}{2(1+\mu)} \\
& \alpha=10(1-\mu)=10(1-0.5)=5
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 14 For the frame shown in the figure (not to scale), all members [latex](A B, B C, C D, G B[/latex], and [latex]C H)[/latex] have the same length, [latex]L[/latex] and flexural rigidity, El. The joints at [latex]B[/latex] and [latex]C[/latex] are rigid joints, and the supports [latex]A[/latex] and [latex]D[/latex] are fixed supports. Beams GB and [latex]\mathrm{CH}[/latex] carry uniformly distributed loads of [latex]w[/latex] per unit length. The magnitude of the moment reaction at [latex]A[/latex] is [latex]\mathrm{wL}^{2} / \mathrm{k}[/latex]. What is the value of [latex]\mathrm{k}[/latex] (in integer) ? ____
solution:
Due to symmetry, slope at mid of [latex]B C[/latex] is zero and can be taken as slider at point [latex]O[/latex] Distribution factors: [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{BA}} & =\frac{4 \mathrm{EI} / \mathrm{L}}{4 \mathrm{EI} / \mathrm{L}+\mathrm{EI} /(\mathrm{L} / 2)}=\frac{2}{3} \\
\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{BO}}&= 1-\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{BA}} \\
& =1-2 / 3=1 / 3 \\
\therefore \quad \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{BA}} & =\frac{\mathrm{WL}^{2}}{2} \times \frac{2}{3}=\frac{\mathrm{WL}^{2}}{3} \\
\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{AB}} & =\frac{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{BA}}}{2}=\frac{\mathrm{WL}^{2} / 3}{2}=\frac{\mathrm{WL}^{2}}{6} \\
& \therefore \mathrm{K}=6
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

Question 23 A uniform rod KJ of weight w shown in the figure rests against a frictionless
vertical wall at the point K and a rough horizontal surface at point J. It is given
that w = 10 kN, a = 4 m and b = 3 m. The minimum coefficient of static friction that is required at the point J to hold
the rod in equilibrium is ___________. (round off to three decimal places)
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned}
\Sigma F_v&=0\\
R_J&=0\\
\Sigma M_K&=0\\
10 \times 1.5+\mu _sR_J \times 4-R_J \times 3&=0\\
\mu _s=\frac{10 \times 3-10 \times 1.5}{10 \times 4}&=0.375
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 24 Consider two linearly elastic rods HI and IJ, each of length b, as shown in the
figure. The rods are co-linear, and confined between two fixed supports at H and
J. Both the rods are initially stress free. The coefficient of linear thermal
expansion is [latex]\alpha [/latex] for both the rods. The temperature of the rod IJ is raised by [latex]\Delta T [/latex],
whereas the temperature of rod HI remains unchanged. An external horizontal
force P is now applied at node I. It is given that [latex]\alpha ={10^{-6} } {\circ} C^{-1},\Delta T=50^{\circ}C,b = 2 m, AE = 10^6N.[/latex]. The axial rigidities of the rods HI and IJ are 2AE and AE, respectively. To make the axial force in rod HI equal to zero, the value of the external
force P (in N) is _________. (round off to the nearest integer)
solution:
[latex] R_A+R_B=P[/latex] [latex]\because  [/latex] There is no axial force in rod HI 
[latex]\therefore R_A=0 [/latex] Now check for rod IJ [latex] \therefore R_B=P[/latex] Now as rod IJ is fixed from both end, so net deflection due to increase in temperature will be zero. [latex] \begin{aligned}
b\alpha T +\left [ -\frac{Pb}{AE} \right ]&= 0\\ 
 b\alpha T &=\frac{Pb}{AE} \\ 
P &= AE\alpha T\\ 
 P&= 10^6 \times 10^{-6} \times 50\\ 
 P&=50N 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 26 Stresses acting on an infinitesimal soil element are shown in the figure (with [latex]\sigma _z \gt \sigma _x[/latex]). The major and minor principal stresses are [latex]\sigma _1[/latex]
and [latex]\sigma _3[/latex], respectively. Considering the compressive stresses as positive, which one of the
following expressions correctly represents the angle between the major
principal stress plane and the horizontal plane?
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned}
\Sigma F_x &=0 \\ 
\sigma _x(BC)-\tau _Z \times (AB)\sigma _1 \sin \theta  &= 0\\ 
\sigma _x\left ( \frac{AC \sin \theta }{\cos \theta } \right )+\tau _{zx}\left ( \frac{AC \cos \alpha  }{\cos \theta } \right ) &=\sigma _1 \frac{AC \sin \theta }{\cos \theta }\\ 
\sigma _x \tan \theta +\tau _{zx} &=\sigma _1 \tan \theta  \\ 
\tan \theta(\sigma _1-\sigma _2) &= \tau _{zx}\\ 
 \tan \theta &= \left ( \frac{\tau _{zx}}{\sigma _1-\sigma _x} \right )
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 27 For a linear elastic and isotropic material, the correct relationship among Young's modulus of elasticity ([latex]E[/latex]), Poisson's ratio ([latex]v[/latex]), and shear modulus ([latex]G[/latex]) is

question: Question 31 A solid circular torsional member OPQ is subjected to torsional moments as shown in the figure (not to scale). The yield shear strength of the constituent material is 160 MPa. The absolute maximum shear stress in the member (in MPa, round off to one decimal place) is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau_{\max _{O P}}=\frac{16 T_{O P}}{\pi d_{O P}^{3}}=\frac{16 \times 3 \times 10^{3}}{\pi \times 100^{3}}=15.27 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \tau_{\max \mathrm{PQ}}=\frac{16 T_{P Q}}{\pi d_{P Q}^{3}}=\frac{16 \times 1 \times 10^{6}}{\pi \times 80^{3}}=9.94 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}\\ \tau_{\max }=9.94 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Absolute max shear stress [latex]= 15.27 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 32 A single story building model is shown in the figure. The rigid bar of mass 'm' is supported by three massless elastic columns whose ends are fixed against rotation. For the lateral deflection profile of the columns as shown in the figure, the natural frequency of the system for horizontal oscillation is
solution: As the deflection will be same in all the 3 columns, so it represents a parallel connection. [latex]\begin{aligned} k_{e q} &=3 k=\frac{36 E I}{L^{3}} \\ \text { Natural frequency }(\omega) &=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}} \\ &=\sqrt{\frac{36 E I}{m L^{3}}}=6 \sqrt{\frac{E I}{m L^{3}}} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 35 The equation of deformation is derived to be [latex]y=x^{2}-x L[/latex] for a beam shown in the figure. The curvature of the beam at the mid-span (in units, in integer) will be ______________

question: Question 36 The state of stress in a deformable body is shown in the figure. Consider transformation of the stress from the x-y coordinate system to the X-Y coordinate system. The angle [latex]\theta[/latex], locating the X-axis, is assumed to be positive when measured from the x-axis in counter-clockwise direction. The absolute magnitude of the shear stress component [latex]\sigma_{\mathrm{xy}}[/latex] (in MPa,round off to one decimal place) in x-y coordinate system is ________________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}  \sigma_{x}^{\prime}&=\frac{\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}}{2}+\left(\frac{\sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y}}{2}\right) \cos 2 \theta+\tau_{x y} \sin 2 \theta \\ \text { Here } \theta=60^{\circ} \\ \sigma_{x}&=40 \mathrm{MPa}, \sigma_{y}=35.6, \sigma_{x}^{\prime}=120, \tau_{x^{\prime} y^{\prime}}=-50 \end{aligned}[/latex] Substituting the values in above equation, we get [latex]\tau_{x y}=96.186 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex]

question:
Question 37 Joints I, J, K, L, Q and M of the frame shown in the figure (not drawn to the scale)
are pins. Continuous members IQ and IJ are connected through a pin at N. Continuous
members JM and KQ are connected through a pin at P. The frame has hinge supports
at joints R and S. The loads acting at joints I, J and K are along the negative Y direction
and the loads acting at joints I, M are along the positive X direction. The magnitude of the horizontal component of reaction (in kN) at S, is
solution: Remove hinge at support S and replace it with roller support as shown in the figure. Step One : Find coordinates of all the points where forces are acting [latex]\begin{aligned} y_I&=\sqrt{2} \sin \theta \\ y_J&=\sqrt{2} \sin \theta \\ y_K&=\sqrt{2} \sin \theta \\ x_L&=\sqrt{2} \cos \theta \\ x_M&=5\sqrt{2} \cos \theta \\ x_S&=6\sqrt{2} \cos \theta \end{aligned}[/latex] Step Two: Find virtual displacements of all the points [latex]\begin{aligned} \delta y_I&=\sqrt{2} \cos \theta d\theta \\ \delta y_J&=\sqrt{2} \cos \theta d\theta \\ \delta y_K&=\sqrt{2} \cos \theta d\theta \\ \delta x_L&=-\sqrt{2} \sin \theta d\theta \\ \delta x_M&=-5\sqrt{2} \sin \theta d\theta \\ \delta x_S&=-6\sqrt{2} \sin \theta d\theta \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Step Three : Use principle of virtual work to find unknown horizontal force [latex]H_s[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \delta U=0[/latex] [latex]=[-10 \times \sqrt{2} \cos \theta d\theta ] \times 3 + [-10 \times -\sqrt{2} \cos \theta d\theta ] +[-10 \times -5\sqrt{2} \sin \theta d\theta ] - [-H_S \times -6\sqrt{2} \sin \theta d\theta ][/latex] [latex]H_S=\frac{30\sqrt{2} \cos \theta +10\sqrt{2} \sin \theta +50\sqrt{2} \sin \theta}{6\sqrt{2} \sin \theta}[/latex] Substituting, [latex]\theta =45^{\circ},\; H_S=\frac{90}{6}=15kN[/latex] Note : Sign conventions If a force acts along positive x or positive y-axis, take it as positive. If a force acts along negative x or negative y-axis, take it as negative.

question: Question 40 A rigid, uniform, weightless, horizontal bar is connected to three vertical members P, Q and R as shown in the figure. All three members have identical axial stiffness of 10 kN/mm. The lower ends of bars P and R rest on a rigid horizontal surface. When NO laod is applied, a gap of 2 mm exist between the lower end of the bar Q and the rigid horizontal surface. When a vertical load W is placed on the horizontal bar in the downward direction, the bar still remains horizontal and gets displayed by 5 mm in the vertically downward direction. The magnitude of the load W (in kN, round off to the nearst integer), is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_1 +P_1+P_2&=W \\ P_1&=P_3 \\ \frac{AE}{L}&=10kN/mm\\ \delta _1&=5mm=\frac{P_1L}{AE} \\ \delta _2&=3 mm = \frac{P_2L}{AE} \\ P_1 &=10 \times 5 =50 kN \\ P_2 &=10 \times 3 =30kN \\ W&=2(20)+30=130 kN \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 42 A cantilever beam PQ of uniform flexural rigidity (EI) is subjected to a concentrated

OJ and four weightless, frictionless rollers. Point O and J are pin connections. A block

point P, is

question: Question 45 A plane frame shown in the figure has linear elastic springs at node H. The spring constants are [latex]k_x=k_y=5 \times 10^5kN/m[/latex] and [latex]k_\theta =3 \times 10^5kNm/rad[/latex]. For the externally applied moment of 30 kNm at node F, the rotation (in degrees, round off to 3 decimals) observed in the rotational spring at node H is_____
solution: No moment can be taken by segment FE. [latex]\therefore \;\;M_{FE}=0[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} M_\theta &=k_\theta \times \theta \\ 30kNm&=3 \times 10^5 \times \theta \\ \theta &=1 \times 10^{-4} \; \text{radians} \\ &=0.0057^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 For a plane stress problem, the state of stress at a point P is represented by the stress element as shown in figure. By how much angle ([latex]\theta[/latex]) in degrees the stress element should be rotated in order to get the planes of maximum shear stress?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma _x&=80\\ \sigma _y&=-20\\ \sigma _z&=-25 \end{aligned}[/latex] Angle of plane of max shear [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta &=\theta _p+45^{\circ}\\ \tan 2\theta _p&=\frac{2\tau _{xy}}{\sigma _x-\sigma _y}\\ &=\frac{-50}{100}\\ \theta _p&=-13.28^{\circ}\\ \therefore \;\;\theta &=31.71^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 47 A closed thin-walled tube has thickness, t, mean enclosed area within the boundary of the centerline of tube's thickness, [latex]A_m[/latex], and shear stress, [latex]\tau[/latex]. Torsional moment of resistance, T, of the section would be
solution: Shear Stress, [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau &=\frac{T}{J}R=\frac{T}{2 \pi R^3 t}R \\ \tau &=\frac{T}{2 \pi R^2 t}=\frac{T}{2 A_m t} \\ T &=2\tau A_mt \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 48 The cross-section of a built-up wooden beam as shown in the figure is subjected to a vertical shear force of 8 kN. The beam is symmetrical about the neutral axis (N.A.) shown, and the moment of inertia about N.A. is [latex]1.5 \times 10^9 mm^4[/latex]. Considering that the nails at the location P are spaced longitudinally (along the length of the beam) at 60 mm, each of the nails at P will be subjected to the shear force of
solution: Shear stress acting at the joint at which the nail 'P' is resisting the shear. [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau &=\frac{FA\bar{y}}{Ib}\\ &=\frac{(8 \times 10^3)(50 \times 100)(150)}{1.5 \times 10^9 \times 50}\\ &=0.08N/mm^2 \end{aligned}[/latex] The shear force acting on nail at 'P'. [latex]F=\tau (60\times 50)=240N[/latex]

question: Question 49 An isolated concrete pavement slab of length L is resting on a frictionless base. The temperature of the top and bottom fibre of the slab are [latex]T_t \; and \; T_b[/latex], respectively. Assuming [latex]T_t \gt T_b[/latex] and the unit weight of concrete as zero, the maximum thermal stress is calculated as

question: Question 50 An element is subjected to biaxial normal tensile strains of 0.0030 and 0.0020. The normal strain in the plane of maximum shear strain is
solution: [latex]\varepsilon _x=0.0030[/latex] [latex] \varepsilon _y=0.0020 [/latex] Normal strain in the plane of maximum shear strain [latex]\varepsilon _{avg}=\frac{\varepsilon _x+\varepsilon _y}{2}=\frac{0.0030+0.0020}{2}=0.0025[/latex]

question: Question 51 An 8 m long simply-supported elastic beam of rectangular cross-section (100 mm x 200mm) is subjected to a uniformly distributed load of 10 kN/m over its entire span. The maximum principal stress (in MPa, up to two decimal places) at a point located at the extreme compression edge of a cross-section and at 2 m from the support is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_A+V_B&=80\\ V_A&=V_B=40\\ &\text{[Due to symmetry]}\\ M_A&=(-10\times 2 \times 1)+40 \times 2\\ &=60 kNm \end{aligned}[/latex] At extreme compression edge, Bending stress, [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma &=\frac{My}{I}\\ &=\frac{(60 \times 10^6) \times \frac{200}{2}}{100 \times \frac{200^3}{12}}\\ &=90MPa \end{aligned}[/latex] Direct share stress = 0 Principal stress, [latex]\sigma_{p1}/\sigma_{p2}=\frac{90+0}{2}\pm \frac{1}{2}\sqrt{(0-90)^2+y(0)^2}[/latex] [latex]\sigma_{p1}=90 MPa[/latex] So, pricipal stress [latex]=90 N/mm^2=90MPa[/latex]

question: Question 52 A plate in equilibrium is subjected to uniform stresses along its edges with magnitude [latex]\sigma_{xx}[/latex] = 30 MPa and [latex]\sigma_{yy}[/latex] = 50 MPa as shown in the figure. The Young's modulus of the material is [latex]2 \times 10^{11} N/m^{2}[/latex] and the Poisson's ratio is 0.3. If [latex]\sigma_{zz}[/latex] is negligibly small and assumed to be zero, then the strain [latex]\varepsilon _{zz}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma _{xx} &=30MPa \\ \sigma _{yy} &=50MPa \\ \sigma _{zz} &=0 \\ \varepsilon _{zz} &=\frac{\sigma _{zz}}{E}-\mu \frac{\sigma _{xx}}{E}-\mu \frac{\sigma _{yy}}{E} \\ &= -\frac{\mu }{E} (\sigma _{xx}+\sigma _{yy})\\ &= -\frac{0.3}{2 \times 10^5}(30+50)\\ &=-120 \times 10^{-6} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 A cantilever beam of length 2 m with a square section of side length 0.1 m is loaded vertically at the free end. The vertical displacement at the free end is 5 mm. The beam is made of steel with Young's modulus of [latex]2.0 \times 10^{11} N/m^{2}[/latex]. The maximum bending stress at the fixed end of the cantilever is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I&=\frac{(0.1)^4}{12} \\ \text{Deflection }\delta &=\frac{Pl^2}{3eI} \\ 5 \times 10^{-3}&=\frac{P(2)^3}{3 \times 2 \times 10^11 \times \frac{(0.1)^4}{12}} \\ P&=3125N \\ \text{Now, } M&= Pl=3125 \times 2\\ &= 6250Nm\\ \text{As, }\frac{M}{I} &=\frac{\sigma }{y}=\frac{E}{R} \\ \sigma _{max}&=\frac{M}{Z}=\frac{6250}{\frac{(0.1)^3}{6}}\\ &=37.5 \times 10^6 N/m^2=37.5MPa \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 A solid circular beam with radius of 0.25 m and length of 2 m is subjected to a twisting moment of 20 kNm about the z-axis at the free end, which is the only load acting as shown in the figure. The shear stress component [latex]\tau_{xy}[/latex] at Point 'M' in the cross-section of the beam at a distance of 1 m from the fixed end is
solution: The only non-zero stresses are [latex]\tau_{\theta z}=\tau_{z \theta}=\tau [/latex] if [latex]\theta[/latex] is [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex] then [latex]\theta=y [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Hence}\quad\tau_{z y} &=\tau_{y z}=\tau_{\max } \\ &=16 T / \pi \mathrm{d}^{3}=0.815 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex] But in rest of the planes shear stresses are zero, hence, [latex]\tau_{x y}=\tau_{y x}=0[/latex]

question: Question 55 A 2 m long, axially loaded mild steel rod of 8 mm diameter exhibits the load-displacement [latex](P-\delta )[/latex] behavior as shown in the figure. Assume the yield stress of steel as 250 Mpa. The complementary energy (in N-mm) stored in the bar up to its linear elastic behavior will be____
solution:
Elastic strain, [latex]\epsilon_{E}=\frac{\Delta L}{L}=\frac{2.5}{2000}=1.25 \times 10^{-2} [/latex] Elastic strain energy [latex]=\frac{1}{2} \sigma_{y} \in_{E} A L [/latex] [latex]
=\frac{1}{2} \times 250 \times 1.25 \times 10^{-3} \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times 8^{2} \times 2000 [/latex] [latex]
 =15707.96 \mathrm{Nmm} [/latex] Note: For linear elastic material both 
complementary energy and strain energy is same.

question: Question 56 A hollow circular shaft has an outer diameter of 100 mm and inner diameter of 50 mm. If the allowable shear stress is 125 MPa, the maximum torque (in kN-m) that the shaft can resist is____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \frac{T}{I_{p}}&=\frac{\tau}{r} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \tau&=\frac{T}{Z_{p}}=\frac{T}{\frac{\pi\left(D^{4}-d^{4}\right)}{16 \times D}}=\frac{16 T}{\frac{\pi}{D}\left(D^{4}-d^{4}\right)} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \tau&=\frac{16 T}{\pi D^{3}\left[1-\left(\frac{d}{D}\right)^{4}\right]} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 125&=\frac{16 T}{\pi(100)^{3}\left[1-\left(\frac{50}{100}\right)^{4}\right]} \\ \Rightarrow \quad T&=23 \mathrm{kNm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 57 Consider the three prismatic beamwith the clamped supports P, Q and R as shown in the figures Given that modulus of Elasticity, E is [latex]2.5\times 10^{4}\, \, MPa;[/latex] and the moment of inertia, [latex]I[/latex] is [latex]8\times 10^{8}\, \, mm^{4}[/latex], the correct Comparison of the magnitudes of the shear force S and the bending moment M developed at the supports is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} S_{P} \lt S_{Q} \gt S_{R} \\ M_{P}=M_{Q}=M_{R} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 58 Two prismatic beams having the same flexural rigidity of 1000 [latex]kN-m^2[/latex] are shown in the figures. If the mid-span deflections of these beams are denoted by [latex]\delta_1 \; and \; \delta _2[/latex] (as indicated in the figures). The correct option is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \delta_{1} &=\frac{5}{384} \times \frac{w l^{4}}{E I} \\ &=\frac{5}{384} \times \frac{6(4)^{4}}{1000}=20 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}\\ \delta_{2}&=\frac{P l^{3}}{48 E I}=\frac{120 \times 2^{3}}{48 \times 1000}=20 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} \\ \therefore \quad \delta_{1}&=\delta_{2} \end{aligned}\\[/latex]

question:
Question 59 In a material under a state of plane strain, a 10x10 mm square centered at a point gets deformed as shown in the figure. If the Shear strain [latex]\gamma _{xy}[/latex]
 at this point is expressed as 0.001k(in rad),the value of k is
solution: According to the sign convention. In question since angle has been increase Therefore, shear strain should be negative. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \; \gamma_{x y} &=-0.0005 \mathrm{rad} \\ &=0.001 k \\ -0.0005 &=0.001 k \\ \Rightarrow \;\; k &=-0.50 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 60 Consider two axially loaded columns, namely, 1 and 2, made of a linear elastic material with Young's modulus [latex]2 \times 10^{5}[/latex]  MPa, square cross- section with side 10 mm, and length 1 m. For Column 1, one end is fixed and the other end is free. For Column 2, one end is fixed and the other end is pinned. Based on the Euler's theory, the ratio (up to one decimal place) of the buckling load of Column 2 to the buckling load of Column 1 is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{c r 1}&=\frac{\pi^{2} E \cdot I}{(2 l)^{2}}=\frac{\pi^{2} E I}{4 l^{2}} \\ P_{c r 2}&=\frac{\pi^{2} E \cdot I}{\left(\frac{l}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{2}}=\frac{2 \pi^{2} E I}{l^{2}}\\ \therefore \text{Required ratio }&=\frac{P_{C r 2}}{P_{c r 1}}=\frac{\frac{2 \pi^{2} E I}{l^{2}}}{\frac{\pi^{2} E I}{4 l^{2}}}=8 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 61 Consider the stepped bar made with a linear elastic material and subjected to an axial load of 1 kN, as shown in the figure. Segments 1 and 2 have cross-sectional are of [latex]100mm^{2}[/latex] and [latex]60mm^{2}[/latex], Young's modulus of [latex]2 \times 10^{5}[/latex] MPa and [latex]3 \times 10^{5}[/latex] MPa, and length of 400mm and 900mm, respectively. The strain energy (in N-mm, up to one decimal place) in the bar due to the axial load is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A_{1}=100 \mathrm{mm}^{2}, & E I=2 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{MPa} \\ A_{2}=60 \mathrm{mm}^{2}, &E I=3 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{MPa} \\ \Delta_{A C}=&\Delta_{A B}+\Delta_{B C} \\ =& \frac{1 \times 10^{3} \times 400}{100 \times 2 \times 10^{5}}+\frac{1 \times 10^{3} \times 900}{60 \times 3 \times 10^{5}} \\ =& 0.02+0.05=0.07 \mathrm{mm} \\ U=\frac{1}{2} \times P \times \Delta&=\frac{1}{2} \times 1 \times 1000 \times 0.07=35 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 62 A simply supported beam is subjected to uniformly distributed load. Which one of the following statements is true?

question: Question 63 An elastic bar of length L, uniform cross sectional area A, coefficient of thermal expansion [latex]\alpha[/latex], and Young's modulus E is fixed at the two ends. The temperature of the bar is increased by T, resulting in an axial stress [latex]\sigma[/latex]. Keeping all other parameters unchanged, if the length of the bar is doubled, the axial stress would be
solution: [latex]\sigma=\alpha T E[/latex] [latex] \therefore \;[/latex] Length have no effect on thermal stress. [latex] \therefore \;[/latex] Axial stress is only [latex]\sigma[/latex].

question: Question 64 A 450 mm long plain concrete prism is subjected to the concentrated vertical loads as shown in the figure. Cross section of the prism is given as 150 mm x 150 mm. Considering linear stress distribution across the cross-section, the modulus of rupture (expressed in MPa) is _______ .
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{BM}_{\mathrm{Q}} &=11.25 \times 150 \\ &=1.6875 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{mm} \\ \Rightarrow\quad \frac{\sigma}{y} &=\frac{M_{Q}}{I} \\ \text{where}\quad y &=\frac{150}{2}=75 \mathrm{mm} \text { and } 1=\frac{(150)^{4}}{12} \\ \Rightarrow\quad \sigma &=\frac{1.6875 \times 10^{6} \times 75}{(150)^{4} / 12}=3 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 65 The portal frame shown in the figure is subjected to a uniformly distributed vertical load w (per unit length). The bending moment in the beam at the joint 'Q' is
solution: As there is no horizontal force, [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Hence } \quad H_{P}=H_{S}&=0 \\ \Sigma M_{Q}=H_{P} \times \frac{L}{2}&=0 \\ \therefore \quad B M \text { at } Q&=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 66 For the stress state (in MPa) shown in the figure, the major principal stress is 10 MPa. The shear stress [latex]\tau[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}&=\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 5+5&=10+\sigma_{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sigma_{2}&=0\\ \text { Now, } \quad \sigma_{1 / 2}&=\frac{\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}}{2} \pm \sqrt{\left(\frac{\sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y}}{2}\right)^{2}+\tau_{x y}^{2}} \\ \therefore \quad \sigma_{1}&=\frac{5+5}{2}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{5-5}{2}\right)^{2}+\tau_{x y}^{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 10&=5+\tau_{x y} \\ \therefore \quad \tau_{x y}&=5 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 67 An elastic isotropic body is in a hydrostatic state of stress as shown in the figure. For no change in the volume to occur, what should be its Poisson's ratio?
solution: Volumetric strain, [latex] \begin{aligned} \epsilon_{\mathrm{v}}&=\left(\frac{\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}+\sigma_{z}}{3}\right)(1-2 \mu)\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\delta V}{V}&=\left(\frac{\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}+\sigma_{z}}{3}\right)(1-2 \mu) \\ \text{As }\quad \Delta V&=0 \\ \Rightarrow\text{ Either }\sigma_{x}&+\sigma_{y}+\sigma_{z}=0 or 1-2 \mu=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 1-2 \mu&=0 \\ \mu&=0.5 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 68 A rigid member ACB is shown in the figure. The member is supported at A and B by pinned and guided roller supports, respectively. A force P acts at C as shown. Let [latex]R_{Ah}\: and\: R_{Bh}[/latex] be the horizontal reactions at supports A and B, respectively, and [latex]R_{Av}[/latex] be the vertical reaction at support A. Self-weight of the member may be ignored. Which one of the following sets gives the correct magnitudes of [latex]R_{Av},\: R_{Bh}\, and\, R_{Ah}[/latex] ?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma F_{y} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad R_{a v} &=P \\ \Sigma F_{x} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad R_{B h} &=R_{A h} \\ \Sigma M_{A} &=0 \\ R_{B h} \times 8-P \times 1.5 &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad R_{B h} &=\frac{1.5 P}{8} \\ \Rightarrow\quad R_{A h} &=\frac{1.5 P}{8} \\ R_{A V} &=P \\ R_{B h} &=\frac{1.5 P}{8} \\ R_{A h} &=\frac{1.5 P}{8} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 69 Two beams PQ (fixed at P and with a roller support at Q, as shown in Figure I, which allows vertical movement) and XZ (with a hinge at Y) are shown in the Figures I and II respectively. The spans of PQ and XZ are L and 2L respectively. Both the beams are under the action of uniformly distributed load (W) and have the same flexural stiffness, EI (where, E and I respectively denote modulus of elasticity and moment of inertia about axis of bending). Let the maximum deflection and maximum rotation be [latex]\delta _{max1} \; and \; \theta _{max1}[/latex]  respectively, in the case of beam PQ and the corresponding quantities for the beam XZ be [latex]\delta _{max2} \; and \; \theta _{max2}[/latex], respectively. Which one of the following relationships is true?
solution: Deflection in beam xy at y= Deflection in beam yz at y [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad \frac{w L^{4}}{8 E I} &-\frac{R L^{3}}{3 E I}=\frac{R L^{3}}{3 E I}+\frac{w L^{4}}{8 E I} \\ & A=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] In beam PQ also at support Q , vertical reaction in zero because of roller support. So, bearn PQ, xy and yz are same [latex] \therefore \quad \theta _{\max 1}=\theta _{\max 2} and \delta_{\max 1 }=\delta_{\max 2}[/latex]

question: Question 70 A 3 m long simply supported beam of uniform cross section is subjected to a uniformly distributed load of w=20kN/m in the central 1 m as shown in the figure If the flexural rigidity (EI) of the Beam is [latex]30\times 10^{6}N-m^{2}[/latex], the Maximum slope (expressed in Radians ) of the deformed beam is:
solution: Due to symmetrical loading, [latex] R_{p}=R_{Q}=\frac{w \times 1}{2}=\frac{w}{2}[/latex] [latex] M_{x}=R_{\rho} x /-\frac{w}{2}(x-1)^{2} /+\frac{W}{2}(x-2)^{2}[/latex] According to Macaulay method [latex] E I \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}=R_{\rho} x /-\frac{w}{2}(x-1)^{2} /+\frac{w}{2}(x-2)^{2}[/latex] After integrating once [latex] E I \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{R_{p} x^{2}}{2}+c_{1} /-\frac{w}{6}(x-1)^{3} /+\frac{w}{6}(x-2)^{3} [/latex] Due to symmetrical loading slope will be zero at mid section (x=1.5 m) [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \text{at }x&=15 \mathrm{m}, \frac{d y}{d x}=0 \\ 0 &=\frac{R_{p}(1.5)^{2}}{2}+c_{1}-\frac{w}{6}(1.5-1)^{3} \\ &=\frac{9 R_{p}}{8}+c_{1}-\frac{w}{48}=\frac{9 w}{16}+c_{1}-\frac{w}{48} \\ \therefore \quad c_{1} &=\frac{w}{48}-\frac{9 w}{16}=-\frac{26 w}{48}=-\frac{13 w}{24} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad[/latex] Equation of slope [latex] E I \cdot \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{R_{p} x^{2}}{2}-\frac{13 w}{24} /-\frac{w}{6}(x-1)^{3} /+\frac{w(x-2)^{3}}{6} [/latex] The slope will be maximum at the support [latex] \therefore \theta_{\max }(x=0)[/latex] [latex] =\frac{-13 w}{24 E I}=\frac{-13 \times 20 \times 10^{3}}{24 \times 30 \times 10^{6}}=-0.361 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{radiar} [/latex] Alternatively. Moment Area Method [latex] \begin{aligned} M_{A} & =P \times x \\ & =10 \times 1=10 \mathrm{kNm} \\ M_{B} & =P_{x}-\frac{W}{2}(x-1)^{2} \\ & =10 \times 1.5-\frac{20 \times 0.5^{2}}{2}=12.5 \mathrm{kNm} \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] \theta_{A}-\theta_{C}=[/latex] Area of M/EI diagram between points P and B [latex]\begin{aligned} &\theta_{B}-\theta_{A}=A_{l}+A_{II}+A_{III}\\ &=\left(\frac{1}{2} \times 1 \times \frac{10}{E I}\right)+\left(0.5 \times \frac{10}{E I}\right)+\left(\frac{2}{3} \times 0.5 \times \frac{2.5}{E I}\right) \\ &=\frac{5}{E I}+\frac{5}{E I}+\frac{0.833}{E I} \\ \theta_{A} &=-\frac{10.833}{E I}=-\frac{10.833 \times 10^{3}}{30 \times 10^{6}} \\ &=-0.3611 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{radians} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 71 A steel strip of length, L = 200 mm is fixed at end A and rests at B on a vertical spring of stiffness, k = 2 N/mm. The steel strip is 5 mm wide and 10 mm thick. A vertical load, P = 50 N is applied at B, as shown in the figure. Considering E = 200 GPa, the force (in N) developed in the spring is _________.
solution: Deflection of point B= Deflection of spring [latex] \Delta_{B}=\frac{(P-R) L^{3}}{3 E I}=\frac{R}{k}[/latex] Where, R= Force in the spring [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \frac{(50-R) 200^{3}}{3 \times 200 \times 10^{3} \times \frac{5 \times 10^{3}}{12}}&=\frac{R}{2} \\ 0.064(50-R)&= R \\ 3.2&=R+0.064 R \\ R &=3.0075 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 72 A simply supported reinforced concrete beam of length 10 m sags while undergoing shrinkage. Assuming a uniform curvature of 0.004 [latex]m^{-1}[/latex]  along the span, the maximum deflection (in m) of the beam at mid-span is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Radius. }R&=\frac{1}{C}=250 \mathrm{m} \\ O A &=\sqrt{250^{2}-5^{2}} \\ &=249.95 \mathrm{m} \\ \text { Deflection } &=A A^{\prime}=250-249.95 \\ &=0.05 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 73 In a system,two connected rigid bars AC and BC are of identical length, L with pin supports at A and B. The bars are interconnected at C by a frictionless hinge. The rotation of the hinge is restrained by a rotational spring of stiffness, k. The system initially assumes a straight line configuration, ACB. Assuming both the bars as weightless, the rotation at supports, A and B, due to a transverse load, P applied at C is
solution: Deflection under load [latex]P=\theta L [/latex] Work done by force [latex]P=\frac{1}{2} P(\theta L) [/latex] Strain energy stored in spring [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{1}{2}[k(2 \theta)](2 \theta) \\ \frac{1}{2} P(\theta L) &=\frac{4 k \theta^{2}}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \theta &=\frac{P L}{4 k} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 74 For the plane stress situation shown in the figure, the maximum shear stress and the plane on which it acts are:

Under hydrostatic loading condition, stresses at a point in all directions are equal and hence no shear stress. Alternatively, [latex]

question: Question 75 A horizontal beam ABC is loaded as shown in the figure below. The distance of the point of contraflexure from end A (in m) is _________.
solution: Reaction at B [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta_{\mathrm{B}}&=0 \text { (Compatibility condition) }\\ \frac{10 \times(0.75)^{3}}{3 E I}&+\frac{2.5 \times 0.75^{2}}{2 E I}-\frac{R_{B} \times 0.75^{3}}{3 E I}=0 \\ \frac{9 R_{B}}{64 E I}&=\frac{135}{64 E I}\\ \therefore \quad \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{B}}&=15 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] BM at a distance x from free end Reaction at B [latex] \begin{aligned} & & \mathrm{BM}_{x} &=10 \times x-15 \times(x-0.25)=0 \\ \Rightarrow & & 10 x &=15 x-3.75 \\ \Rightarrow & & 5 x &=3.75 \\ \therefore & & x &=0.75 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] From end A, distance is 0.25m

question: Question 76 Two beams are connected by a linear spring as shown in the following figure. For a load P as shown in the figure, the percentage of the applied load P carried by the spring is __________.
solution: [latex]\Delta_{\text {spring }}=\Delta_{B}-\Delta_{D}[/latex] Compression of spring [latex] \begin{aligned} =\frac{(P-R) L^{3}}{3 E I}-\frac{R L^{3}}{3 E I}&=\frac{R}{K_{S}} \\ \frac{(P-R) L^{3}}{3 E I}-\frac{R L^{3}}{3 E I}&=\frac{R \times\left(2 L^{3}\right)}{3 E I}\\ (P-A)-R &=2 R \\ P &=4 R \\ R &=\frac{P}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex] % force carried by spring =25 %

question: Question 77 A tapered circular rod of diameter varying from 20 mm to 10 mm is connected to another uniform circular rod of diameter 10 mm as shown in the following figure. Both bars are made of same material with the modulus of elasticity, [latex]E=2\times 10^{5}[/latex] MPa. When subjected to a load [latex]P=30\pi kN[/latex] , the deflection at point A is ______ mm.
solution: Total elongation, [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta &=\Delta_{A B}+\Delta_{B C} \\ &=\frac{P L}{A E}+\frac{4 P L}{\pi d_{1} d_{2} E} \\ &=\frac{30 \pi \times 1.5}{\frac{\pi \times(0.01)^{2}}{4} \times 2 \times 10^{5}} \\ &+\frac{30 \pi \times 2}{\frac{\pi \times(0.01) \times(0.02)}{4} \times 2 \times 10^{5}} \\ &=9+6=15 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 80 The tension (in kN) in a 10m long cable, shown in figure, neglecting its self-weight is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma F_{y} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad 2 \text{Tc} 0 s \theta &=120 \\ \text{Here, }\quad \cos \theta &=\frac{4}{5} \\ 2 T \times \frac{4}{5}&=120 \\ \Rightarrow\quad T=\frac{120 \times 5}{2 \times 4}&=75 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 81 The axial load (in kN) in the member PQ for the arrangement/assembly shown in the figure given below is__________
solution: Free body diagram For principle of superposition [latex]\frac{160 \times 2^{3}}{3 E I}+\frac{160 \times 2^{2}}{2 E I} \times 2-\frac{V_{Q} L^{3}}{3 E I}=\frac{V_{Q} L}{A E} \quad \ldots(i)[/latex] Deflections due to axial forces will be very less as compared to bending forces. So we can neglect the axial deformation. [latex] \therefore[/latex] From equation (i) [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{160 \times 2^{3}}{3 E I}+\frac{160 \times 2^{2}}{2 E I} \times 2-\frac{V_{0} 4^{3}}{3 E I}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{160 \times 2^{3}}{3}+\frac{160 \times 2^{2} \times 2}{2}&=\frac{V_{Q} \times 4^{3}}{3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{Q}&=50 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 82 The beam of an overall depth 250 mm (shown below) is used in a building subjected to two different thermal environments. The temperatures at the top and bottom surfaces of the beam are 36[latex]^{\circ} C[/latex] and 72[latex]^{\circ} C[/latex]  respectively. Considering coefficient of thermal expansion ([latex]\alpha[/latex]) as [latex]1.50 \times 10^{-5}[/latex] per [latex]^{\circ} C[/latex], the vertical deflection of the beam (in mm) at its mid-span due to temperature gradient is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} R&=\frac{h}{\alpha T}\\ \text{From properties }&\text{of circle}\\ (2 R-\delta) \delta=\frac{L}{2} \times \frac{L}{2}\\ \text{(Considering }'&\delta ' \text{very small so neglect }\delta^{2} )\\ \Rightarrow \quad \delta=\frac{L^{2}}{8 R}=\frac{L^{2} \alpha T}{8 h}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} Given, \alpha&=1.50 \times 10^{-5} /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \delta&=\frac{\alpha T L^{2}}{8 h} \\ &=\frac{1.50 \times 10^{-5} \times(72-36) \times 3^{2}}{8 \times\left(250 \times 10^{-3}\right)} \\ &=2.43 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 83 The values of axial stress ([latex]\sigma[/latex]) in kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex], bending moment (M) in kNm, and shear force (V) in kN acting at point P for the arrangement shown in the figure are respectively

question: Question 84 For the cantilever beam of span 3 m (shown below), a concentrated load of 20 kN applied at the free end causes a vertical displacement of 2 mm at a section located at a distance of 1 m from the fixed end. If a concentrated vertically downward load of 10 kN is applied at the section located at a distance of 1 m from the fixed end (with no other load on the beam), the maximum vertical displacement in the same beam (in mm) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text { From Betti's law } P_{1} \times \Delta_{12}=P_{2} \times \Delta_{21}\\ &\Rightarrow \quad 10 \times 2=20 \times \Delta_{21}\\ &\Rightarrow \quad \Delta_{21}=1 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 85 A box of weight 100 kN shown in the figure is to be lifted without swinging. If all forces are coplanar, the magnitude and direction ([latex]\theta[/latex]) of the force (F) with respect to x-axis should be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma F_{\text {horizontal }} &=0 \\ 90 \mathrm{cos} 30^{\circ} &=40 \mathrm{cos} 45^{\circ}+\mathrm{F} \cos \theta \\ 77.94 &=28.28+\mathrm{F} \cos \theta \\ \text{or}\quad \mathrm{F} \cos \theta &=49.66 \mathrm{kN}&\ldots(i)\\ \Sigma F_{\text {vertical }}&=0\\ 90 \sin 30^{\circ}&+40 \sin 45^{\circ}+F \sin \theta=W \\ 45+28.28+F \sin \theta&=100 \\ \text{or}\quad \quad F \sin \theta&=26.72 \mathrm{kN} &\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Dividing eq. (ii) by eq. (i), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \tan \theta &=\frac{26.72}{49.66}=0.5380 \\ \text{or}\quad\theta &=\tan ^{-1}(0.5380)=28.28^{\circ}\\ \text{Substituting }\theta&=28.28 \text{ in eq. (i), we get}\\ F \cos 28.28^{\circ} &=49.66 \\ \text{or}\quad F &=\frac{49.66}{\cos 28.28^{\circ}}\\ &=\frac{49.66}{0.88}=56.43 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 86 If the following equation establishes equilibrium in slightly bent position, the mid-span deflection of a member shown in the figure is: [latex]\frac{d^2 y}{ dx^2}+\frac{P}{EI}y=0[/latex] If a is amplitude constant for y, then
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}} &=-\frac{P}{E I} x y \\ &=-m^{2} y \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Solution of above differential equation is [latex] \begin{aligned} y&=a \sin m x+b \cos m x \\ \text{at }\quad x&=0, y=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad b&=0 \\ \text{at }\quad x&=L, y=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0&=\sin m L \\ \Rightarrow \quad m L&=n \pi \\ \Rightarrow \quad m&=\frac{n \pi}{L} \\ \therefore \quad y&=a \sin \frac{n \pi x}{L} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 87 The possible location of shear centre of the channel section, shown below, is

question: Question 88 A uniform beam (EI=constant) PQ in the form of a quarter-circle of radius R is fixed at end P and free at the end Q, where a load W is applied as shown. The vertical downward displacement, [latex]\delta _{q}[/latex], at the loaded point Q is given by: [latex]\delta _{q}=\beta (\frac{WR^{3}}{EI})[/latex]. Find the value of [latex]\beta[/latex](correct to 4-decimal places). __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} U &=\int \frac{M^{2} d x}{2 E l}=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{(W R \sin \theta)^{2} R d \theta}{2 E l} \\ &=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{P^{2} R^{3}}{2 E l} \sin ^{2} \theta d \theta \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{P^{2} R^{3}}{2 E I} \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{(1-\cos 2 \theta) d \theta}{2} \\ &=\frac{P^{2} R^{3}}{4 E I}\left[\theta-\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2}\right]_{0}^{\pi / 2} \\ &=\frac{P^{2} R^{3}}{4 E I}\left[\frac{\pi}{2}\right]=\frac{P^{2} R^{3} \pi}{8 E I} \\ \therefore \quad \delta_{Q}&=\frac{\partial U}{\partial W}=\frac{2 P R^{3} \pi}{8 E I}=\frac{P R^{3}}{E I} \frac{\pi}{4} \\ \therefore \quad \delta_{Q}&=\frac{\pi}{4}\left(\frac{W R^{3}}{E !}\right) \\ \therefore \quad \beta&=\frac{\pi}{4}=0.7854 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 89 The state of 2D-stress at a point is given by the following matrix of stresses: [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \sigma _{xx} & \sigma _{xy}\\ \sigma _{xy} & \sigma _{yy} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 100 &30 \\ 30& 20 \end{bmatrix}MPa[/latex] What is the magnitude of maximum shear stressin MPa?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma_{1 / 2} &=\frac{\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}}{2} \pm \sqrt{\left(\frac{\sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y}}{2}\right)^{2}+\tau_{x y}^{2}} \\ &=\frac{100+20}{2} \pm \sqrt{\left(\frac{100-20}{2}\right)^{2}+(30)^{2}} \\ &=60 \pm 50 \\ \sigma_{1} &=110 ; \sigma_{2}=10 \\ \therefore \tau_{\max } &=\frac{\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}}{2}=\frac{110-10}{2}=50 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 90 A symmetric I-section (with width of each flange = 50 mm, thickness of each flange = 10 mm,
depth of web = 100 mm, and thickness of web = 10 mm) of steel is subjected to a shear force of
100 kN. Find the magnitude of the shear stress(in [latex]N/mm^{2}[/latex]) in the web at its junction with the top flange. __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} 1 &=\frac{50 \times 120^{3}}{12}-\frac{40 \times 100^{3}}{12} \\ &=3.866 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{mm}^{4} \\ q &=\frac{S A \bar{y}}{16}=\frac{100 \times 10^{3} \times 50 \times 10 \times 55}{3.866 \times 10^{6} \times 10} \\ &=71.12 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 91 Two steel columns P (length L and yield strength [latex]f_{y}[/latex]= 250 MPa) and Q (length 2L and yield strength [latex]f_{y}[/latex]= 500 MPa) have the same cross-sections and end-conditions. The ratio of buckling load of column P to that of column Q is:
solution: Buckling load, [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=\frac{\pi^{2} E \mid}{\left(l_{e f f}\right)^{2}} \\ \therefore \quad P_{p} &=\frac{\pi^{2} E \mid}{(L)^{2}} ; P_{Q}=\frac{\pi^{2} E \mid}{(2 L)^{2}} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{P_{P}}{P_{a}} &=4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 98 The following statements are related to bending of beams: I The slope of the bending moment diagram is equal to the shear force. and R2 in the springs at points '1' and '2'?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} R_{1} &=k \delta_{1}=k \times \frac{2 P}{5 k} \\ &=\frac{2 \times 100}{5}=40 \mathrm{kN} \\ R_{2} &=k \delta_{2}=k \times \frac{4 P}{5 k} \\ &=\frac{4 \times 100}{5}=80 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: The free diagram of the beam is shown below From similar triangles, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{L}{\delta_{1}}=\frac{2 L}{\delta_{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \delta_{2}=2 \delta_{1} \quad &\ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking moments about hinge, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} P \times 2 L-k \delta_{2} \times 2 L-k \delta_{1} \times L&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 2 P-k\left(2 \delta_{2}+\delta_{1}\right)&=0 &[\therefore\text{ from(i)}]\\ \Rightarrow \quad 2 P-k\left(4 \delta_{1}+\delta_{1}\right)&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \delta_{1}&=\frac{2 P}{5 k} \end{aligned}[/latex] From (i), we get [latex] \delta_{2}=2 \times \frac{2 P}{5 k}=\frac{4 P}{5 k}[/latex]

question:
Question 105 A solid circular shaft of diameter d and length L is fixed at one end free at

question:
Question 109 Two people weighing W each are sitting on a plank of length L floating on water
at L/4 from either end. Neglecting the weight of he plank, the bending moment
at the centre of the plank is
solution: The plank will be balanced by the buoyant force acting under its bottom. Let the intensity of buoyant force be w. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{For equilibrium, }w \times L&=W+W \\ \Rightarrow \quad w&=\frac{2 W}{L}\text{ upwards}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Thus, the bending moment at the centre of the plank will be [latex] \begin{aligned} M &=\frac{2 W}{L} \times \frac{L}{2} \times \frac{L}{4}-W \times \frac{L}{4} \\ \Rightarrow \quad M&=\frac{W L}{4}-\frac{W L}{4}=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 110 In the cantilever beam PQR shown in figure below, the segment PQ has flexural
rigidity EI and the segment QR has infinite flexural rigidity. The deflection of the beam at R is
solution: since the portion QR of the beam is rigid, QR will remain straight. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Deflection of } R &=\Delta_{1}+\Delta_{2} \\ &=\text { Deflection at } Q \\ &+\text { Slope at } Q \times L \\ &=\frac{5 W L^{3}}{6 E I}+\frac{3 W L^{2}}{2 E I} \times L \\ &=\frac{5 W L^{3}+9 W L^{3}}{6 E I} \\ &=\frac{14 W L^{3}}{6 E I}=\frac{7 W L^{3}}{3 E I} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:

question: Question 113 A hollow circular shaft has an outer diameter of 100 mm and a wall thickness of 25 mm. The allowable shear stress in the shaft is 125 MPa. The maximum torque the shaft can transmit is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore\quad \frac{T}{I_{P}} &=\frac{\tau}{R} \\ \Rightarrow \quad T &=\frac{\tau}{R} \times I_{P} \\ &=125 \times \frac{\pi}{32} \times\left(100^{4}-50^{4}\right) \times \frac{2}{100} \times 10^{-6} \\ &=23.00 \mathrm{kN}-\mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 117 Beam GHI is supported by three pontoons as shown in the figure below. The horizontal cross-sectional area of each pontoon is [latex]8 m^{2}[/latex], the flexural rigidity of the beam is 10000 [latex]kN-m^{2}[/latex] 
 and the unit weight of water is 10[latex]kN/m^{3}[/latex] When the middle pontoon is brought back to its position as shown in the figure above, the reaction at H will be
solution: Let the elastic deflection at H be [latex]\delta_{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \delta_{2}&=\frac{(P-R) L^{3}}{48 E I} \quad &\ldots(i)\end{aligned}[/latex] The reactions at G and I will be same, as the beam is symmetrically loaded. Let the reaction at each G and I be Q Using principle of buoyancy, we get [latex] \delta_{1} \times [/latex] area of cross-section of pontoon [latex]\times \gamma_{w}=Q [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad \delta_{1} \times 8 \times 10&=Q \\ \Rightarrow \quad \delta_{1}&=\frac{Q}{80} &\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Also, we have [latex] \begin{aligned} Q+Q+R&=P \\ \Rightarrow \quad 2 Q+R&=48 &\ldots(iii)\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \text{Also, }\left(\delta_{1}+\delta_{2}\right) \times [/latex] area of cross-section of Pontoon [latex]\times \gamma_{n}=\mathrm{R} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow\left(\delta_{1}+\delta_{2}\right) \times 8 \times 10&=\mathrm{R} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \delta_{1}+\delta_{2}&=\frac{R}{80} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{Q}{80}+\delta_{2}&=\frac{R}{80} &[\text{from (ii)}]\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{48-R}{2 \times 80}+\delta_{2}&=\frac{R}{80} \quad&[\text{from (iii)}] \\ \Rightarrow \quad \delta_{2}&=\frac{2 R-48+R}{160} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \delta_{2}&=\frac{3 R-48}{160} \\ \therefore \frac{(48-R) \times 10^{3}}{48 \times 10^{4}}&=\frac{3 R-48}{160} \quad&[\text{from (i)}] \\ \Rightarrow \quad R&=19.2 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 118 Beam GHI is supported by three pontoons as shown in the figure below. The horizontal cross-sectional area of each pontoon is [latex]8 m^{2}[/latex], the flexural rigidity of the beam is 10000 [latex]kN-m^{2}[/latex]

The deflection at H will be due to the load at H as well as due to the downward settlement of pontoons at G and l in water. question: Question 120 The maximum tensile stress at the section X-X shown in the figure below is

question: Question 121 A vertical rod PQ of length L is fixed at its top end P and has a flange fixed to the bottom end Q. A weight W is dropped vertically from a height h ([latex]\lt[/latex]L) on to the flange. The axial stress in the rod can be reduced by
solution:
The kinetic energy of the weight (W) at flange level will be transformed in the form of strain energy in 
the rod. We know that [latex] \mathrm{U}=\sigma^{2} / 2 \mathrm{E} \times [/latex] Area of cross-section of rod [latex] \times [/latex] length of rod Since, energy remains constant, hence to reduce the axial stress in the rod, the length of the rod 
should be increased or area of cross-section of 
the rod should be increased or modulus of 
elasticity should be decreased.

options.A: increasing the length of the rod
options.B: decreasing the length of the rod
options.C: decreasing the area of cross-section of the rod
options.D: increasing the modulus of elasticity of the material

question: Question 122 The maximum shear stress in a solid shaft of circular cross-section having diameter d subjected to a subject to a torque T is [latex]\tau[/latex]. If the torque is increased by four times and the diameter of the shaft is increased by two times, the maximum shear stress in the shaft will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \frac{\tau}{R}&=\frac{T}{I_{P}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\tau_{1}}{\tau_{2}}&=\frac{R_{1}}{R_{2}} \times \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}} \times \frac{I_{P_{2}}}{I_{P_{1}}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\tau_{1}}{\tau_{2}}&=\frac{R_{1}}{2 R_{1}} \times \frac{T_{1}}{4 T_{1}} \times\left(\frac{2 R_{1}}{R_{1}}\right)^{4} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\tau_{1}}{\tau_{2}}&=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{4} \times 16 \\ \Rightarrow\quad\tau_{2}&=\frac{\tau_{1}}{2} \\ \Rightarrow\quad\tau_{2}&=\frac{\tau}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 123 A rigid bar GH of length L is supported by a hinge and a spring of stiffness K as shown in the figure below. The buckling load, [latex]P_{Cr}[/latex], for the bar will be
solution: Let the deflection in the spring be [latex]\delta[/latex] and force in the spring be F. Taking moments about G, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{c r} \times \delta&=F \times L\\ \Rightarrow \quad P_{c r}&=\frac{K \delta \times L}{\delta} &\left[\because F=K\delta \right ]\\ \Rightarrow \quad P_{c r}&=K L \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 124 Cross-section of a column consisting to two steel strips, each of thickness t and
width b is shown in the figure below. The critical loads of the column with perfect
bond and without bond between the strips are [latex]P[/latex] and [latex]P_0[/latex] respectively. The ratio [latex]P/P_0[/latex] is
solution: We know that critical load for a column is proportional to moment of inertia irrespective of end conditions of the column i.e. [latex] P_{c r} \propto 1[/latex] When the steel strips are perfectly bonded, then [latex] f_{p b}=\frac{b \times(2 t)^{3}}{12}=\frac{8 b t^{3}}{12}[/latex] When the steel strips are not bonded, then [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{wb}&=2 \times \frac{b t^{3}}{12}=\frac{2 b t^{3}}{12} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{P}{P_{0}}&=\frac{8 b t^{3} / 12}{2 b t^{3} / 12}=4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 125 A mild steel specimen is under uniaxial tensile stress. Young's modulus and yield
stress for mild steel are [latex]2 \times 10^{5}[/latex] MPa and 250 MPa respectively. The maximum amount of strain energy per unit volume that can be stored in this specimen
without permanent set is
solution: The strain energy per unit volume may be given as [latex] \begin{aligned} u &=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{\sigma_{y}^{2}}{E}=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{(250)^{2}}{2 \times 10^{5}} \\ &=0.156 \mathrm{N}\; \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{mm}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 126 [latex]U_{1}[/latex] and [latex]U_{2}[/latex] are the Strain energies stored in a prismatic bar due toaxial tensile forces [latex]P_{1}[/latex] and [latex]P_{2}[/latex], respectively. The strain energy U stored in the same bar due to combined action of [latex]P_{1}[/latex] and [latex]P_{2}[/latex] will be
solution: Strain energy stored in a prismatic bar due to axial load [latex] P_{1} [/latex] [latex] U_{1}=\frac{P_{1}^{2} L}{2 A E}[/latex] Strain energy stored in a prismatic bar due to axial load, [latex]P_{2}[/latex] [latex] U_{2}=\frac{P_{2}^{2} L}{2 A E}[/latex] Strain energy stored in a prismatic bar due to combined action of [latex]P_{1}[/latex] and [latex]P_{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} U &=\frac{\left(P_{1}+P_{2}\right)^{2} L}{2 A E} \\ U &=\frac{P_{1}^{2} L}{2 A E}+\frac{P_{2}^{2} L}{2 A E}+\frac{P_{1} P_{2} L}{A E} \\ U&=U_{1}+U_{2}+\frac{P_{1} P_{2} L}{A E} \\ \Rightarrow \quad U&>U_{1}+U_{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 127 The shear stress at the neutral axis in a beam of triangular section with a base of
40 mm and height 20 mm, subjected to a shear force of 3 kN is
solution: [latex]\text { Shear stress, } \tau=\frac{S A \bar{y}}{1 b}[/latex] Width at a distance of [latex]\frac{40}{3} \mathrm{mm}[/latex] from the top [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{40}{20} \times \frac{40}{3}=\frac{80}{3} \mathrm{mm}\\ \therefore \tau &=\frac{3 \times 10^{3} \times\left(\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{80}{3} \times \frac{40}{3}\right) \times\left(\frac{1}{3} \times \frac{40}{3}\right)}{\left(\frac{40 \times 20^{3}}{36}\right) \times \frac{80}{3}} \\ &=\frac{3 \times 10^{3} \times 3200 \times 40 \times 36 \times 3}{162 \times 3200 \times 20^{3}} \\ &=10 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 128 The maximum and minimum shear stresses in a hollow circular shaft of outer
diameter 20 mm and thickness 2 mm, subjected to a torque of 92.7 Nm will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \because \quad \frac{f_{s}}{R} &=\frac{T}{J} \\ \text { Here, } \quad J &=\frac{\pi}{32}\left(20^{4}-16^{4}\right) \mathrm{mm}^{4} \\ R_{1} &=\frac{20}{2}=10 \mathrm{mm} \\ T &=92.7 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m} ; \\ R_{2} &=\frac{16}{2}=8 \mathrm{mm} \\ f_{s_{1}} &=\frac{T R_{1}}{J}=\frac{92.7 \times 10^{3} \times 10}{(\pi / 32) \times\left(20^{4}-16^{4}\right)} \\ &=99.96 \mathrm{MPa} \approx 100 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \text { and } \quad f_{{9}_{2}} &=\frac{T R_{2}}{J}=\frac{92.7 \times 10^{3} \times 8}{(\pi / 32) \times\left(20^{4}-16^{4}\right)} \\ &=79.96 \mathrm{MPa} \simeq 80 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 129 A metal bar of length 100 mm is inserted between two rigid supports and its
temperature is increased by [latex]10^{\circ}C[/latex]. If the coefficient of thermal expansion is [latex]12\times 10^{-6}[/latex] per [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] and the Young's modulus is [latex]2\times 10^{5}[/latex] MPa, the stress in the bar is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Temperature stress } &=\alpha \text { TE } \\ &=12 \times 10^{-6} \times 10 \times 2 \times 10^{5} \\ &=24 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 130 For an isotropic material, the relationship between the Young's modulus (E), shear modulus (G) and Poisson's ratio ([latex]\mu[/latex]) is given by
Question 131 A steel column, pinned at both end, has a buckling load of 200 kN. If the column is restrained against lateral movement at its mid-height, it buckling load will be
solution: When both ends are hinged, the buckling load is given by, [latex] P_{c r}=\frac{\pi^{2} E I}{L^{2}} \Rightarrow 200=\frac{\pi^{2} E l}{L^{2}}[/latex] When the lateral movement at the mid-height is not available, then buckling load [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{\pi^{2} E \mid}{\left(L_{1}\right)^{2}} \quad \text { where } L_{1}=\frac{L}{2} \\ &=\frac{4 \pi^{2} E \mid}{L^{2}}=4 \times 200=800 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 132 An axially loaded bar is subjected to a normal stress of 173 MPa. The stress in the bar is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Shear stress }&=\frac{\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}}{2} \\ \therefore \quad&=\frac{173-0}{2}=86.5 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 133 Consider a propped cantilever beam ABC under two loads of magnitude P each
as shown in the figure below. Flexural rigidity of the beam is EI. The rotation at B is
solution: The rotation at B : (i) Due to moment [latex] \theta_{8_{1}}=\frac{2 P a \times L}{E l} \text { (clockwise) }[/latex] (ii) Due to reaction R [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta_{B_{2}} &=\frac{R L^{2}}{2 E I}+\frac{R L^{2}}{E I}=\frac{3 R L^{2}}{2 E l} \\ &=\frac{27}{16} \frac{P a L}{E l}(\text { anticlockwise }) \\ \therefore\quad \theta_{B} &=\theta_{B_{1}}-\theta_{B_{2}} \\ &=\left(2-\frac{27}{16}\right) \frac{P a L}{E l} \\ &=\frac{5}{16} \frac{P a L}{E l}(\text { clockwise }) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 134 Consider a propped cantilever beam ABC under two loads of magnitude P each
as shown in the figure below. Flexural rigidity of the beam is EI. The reaction at C is
solution: The moment at point B=2 Pa In the cantilever beam ABC, the deflection at C. due to moment 2Pa will be given as [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta &=\frac{M L^{2}}{2 E I}+\frac{M L}{E I} \times L \\ &=\frac{2 P a L^{2}}{2 E I}+\frac{2 P a L}{E I} \times L \\ &=\frac{3 P a L^{2}}{E I}(d o w n w a r d s) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]The reaction at C will be upwards [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta_{c}^{\prime} &=\frac{R(2 L)^{3}}{3 E I} \\ &=\frac{8 R L^{3}}{3 E I}(\text { upwards })\\ \text{Thus},\quad \delta_{\mathrm{e}} &=\delta_{\mathrm{c}}^{\prime} \\ \frac{3 \mathrm{PaL}^{2}}{\mathrm{EI}} &=\frac{8 \mathrm{RL}^{3}}{3 \mathrm{EI}}\\ \Rightarrow \quad R&=\frac{9 P a}{8 L} (upwards) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 135 Vertical reaction developed at B in the frame below due to the applied load to 100 kN (with 150,000[latex]mm^{2}[/latex] cross-sectional area and [latex]3.125\times 10^{9}mm^{4}[/latex] moment of inertia for both members) is
solution: Deflection at A in beam AB= Compression in column AC [latex] \begin{array}{l} \begin{aligned} \quad \frac{(100-\mathrm{R}) \mathrm{L}^{3}}{3 \mathrm{E} 1}&=\frac{\mathrm{RL}}{\mathrm{AE}} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{(100-\mathrm{R}) \times(1 \times 1000)^{3}}{3 \times 3.125 \times 10^{9}}&=\frac{\mathrm{R}}{150000} \\ \end{aligned}\\ \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad 100-\mathrm{R}&=0.0625 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 100&=1.0625 \mathrm{R} \\ \therefore \quad V_{B}&=100-R\\ \Rightarrow \quad \mathrm{R}&=94.1 \mathrm{kN} \\ &=100-\mathrm{R} \\ &=5.9 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 136 A thin-walled long cylindrical tank of inside radius r is subjected simultaneously
to internal gas pressure p and axial compressive force F at its ends. In order to
produce 'pure shear' state of stress in the wall of the cylinder, F should be equal to
solution: [latex]\text { Hoop stress, } \sigma_{\mathrm{h}}=\frac{p r}{t}[/latex] Longitudinal stress, [latex] \sigma_{z}=\frac{p r}{2 t}-\frac{F}{2 \pi r t}[/latex] Now, for pure shear state, [latex]\sigma_{z}[/latex] should be compressive and is equal to [latex]\sigma_{r} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \sigma_{n}&=-\sigma_{z} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{p r}{t}&=-\frac{p r}{2 t}+\frac{F}{2 \pi r t} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{3 p r}{2 t}&=\frac{F}{2 \pi r t} \\ \Rightarrow \quad F&=3 \pi p r^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 137 If a beam of rectangular cross-section is subjected to a vertical shear force V , the
shear force carried by the upper one-third of the cross-section is
solution: Shear stress at distance y from neutral axis, [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau&=\frac{S A \bar{y}}{1 b} =\frac{V \times\left(\frac{d}{2}-y\right) \times b \times\left(\frac{(d / 2)+y}{2}\right)}{16} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \tau&= \frac{V \times\left(\frac{d^{2}}{4}-y^{2}\right)}{21}\\ \therefore \quad d F&=\tau \times b d y=\frac{V \times\left(\frac{d^{2}}{4}-y^{2}\right)}{21} \times b d y\\ \end{aligned} [/latex] Integrating both sides, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad F &=\frac{V b^{d / 2}}{21} \int_{d / 6}^{d}\left(\frac{d^{2}}{4}-y^{2}\right) d y \\ &=\frac{V b}{21}\left[\frac{d^{2}}{4} y-\frac{y^{3}}{3}\right]_{d / 6}^{d / 2} \\ &=\frac{V b}{21}\left[\frac{d^{3}}{8}-\frac{d^{3}}{24}-\frac{d^{3}}{24}+\frac{d^{3}}{648}\right] \\ &=\frac{V b}{21} \times \frac{d^{3}}{8} \times \frac{28}{81} \\ &=\frac{V b}{2 b d^{3}} \times \frac{d^{3}}{8} \times \frac{28}{81} \times 12=\frac{7 V}{27} \end{aligned}[/latex]

below. If this beam transmits a constant vertical shear force of 3000 N, the glue at
any of the four joint will be subjected to a shear force (in kN per meter length) of
solution: Considering shaded area 'abcd' of plank. [latex] \text { Shear flow, } \quad a=\frac{V Q}{1}[/latex] Shear flow is measured as force per unit length along the longitudinal axis of a beam and over the cross-section is as shown above. [latex] \begin{aligned} Q &=A \bar{y} \\ Q &=(75 \times 50) \times 125 \\ &=468750 \mathrm{mm}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Moment of inertia of I-section about NA. [latex] \begin{aligned} 1&=350 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{mm}^{4}\\ V &=3000 N \\ q &=\frac{468750 \times 3000}{350 \times 10^{6}} \\ &=4.018 N / m m \end{aligned}[/latex] So, resistance offered by glue to keep I-section intact. [latex] \mathrm{q}=4.018 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm} \simeq 4 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question:
Question 148 The components of strain tensor at a point in the plane strain case can be
obtained by measuring longitudinal strain in following directions
solution:
In case of plane strain condition, the components of strain tensor at a point are [latex]\epsilon_{x}, \in_{y} \text{ and }\phi_{x y} .[/latex] Here we have three unknowns so we require 3 
equations to find them and these unknowns can 
be find by the equations of longitudinal strain, [latex]
 \epsilon_{1}=\epsilon_{x} \cos ^{2} \theta_{1}+\epsilon_{y} \sin ^{2} \theta_{1}+\frac{\phi_{x y}}{2} \sin 2 \theta_{1} [/latex] [latex]
 \epsilon_{2}=\epsilon_{x} \cos ^{2} \theta_{2}+\epsilon_{y} \sin ^{2} \theta_{2}+\frac{\phi_{x y}}{2} \sin 2 \theta_{2} [/latex] [latex]
 \epsilon_{3}=\epsilon_{x} \cos ^{2} \theta_{3}+\epsilon_{y} \sin ^{2} \theta_{3}+\frac{\phi_{x y}}{2} \sin 2 \theta_{3} [/latex] Therefore to find out component of strain tensor in 
plain strain condition, we measure longitudinal 
strains [latex]\left(\epsilon_{1}, \epsilon_{2}\text{ and }\epsilon_{3}\right)[/latex] along any three arbitrary direction.

question: Question 149 The symmetry of stress tensor at a point in the body under equilibrium is obtained from
solution: Taking moment equilibrium about the centre, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau_{y x} \times \frac{d}{2}+\tau_{y x} \times \frac{d}{2}&=\tau_{x y} \times \frac{d}{2}+\tau_{x y} \times \frac{d}{2} \\ \therefore \quad \tau_{x y}&=\tau_{y x} \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \frac{G \theta}{L}&=\frac{T}{J} \\ \therefore \quad \theta&=\frac{T L}{G J}=\frac{100 \times 5}{50000} \\ &=0.01 \mathrm{rad} \\ \text { Also, torsional strain energy }&=\frac{1}{2} T \theta \\ &=\frac{1}{2} \times 100 \times 0.01 \\ &=0.5 \mathrm{kN}-\mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.B: Statement I is true but II is false
options.C: Statement II is true but I is false

question: Question 153 In a two dimensional stress analysis, the state of stress at a point is shown below. If [latex]\sigma[/latex] = 120 MPa and [latex]\tau[/latex] = 70 MPa, then  [latex]\sigma _{x} \; and \; \sigma _{y}[/latex] are respectively
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { Let } \angle \mathrm{CAB}=\theta \\ \therefore \sin \theta=\frac{3}{5} ; \cos \theta=\frac{4}{5} ; \tan \theta=\frac{3}{4} \end{array}[/latex] Thus from force equilibrium, [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{x} \times A B&=A C \times(\sigma \cos \theta-\tau \sin \theta)\\ \Rightarrow \quad \sigma_{x}&=\frac{5}{4} \times\left(120 \times \frac{4}{5}-70 \times \frac{3}{5}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sigma_{x}&=67.5 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \text{And, }\sigma_{y} \times B C&=A C \times(\sigma \sin \theta+\tau \cos \theta) \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sigma_{y}&=\frac{5}{3} \times\left(120 \times \frac{3}{5}+70 \times \frac{4}{5}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sigma_{y}&=213.3 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 154 For the linear elastic beam shown in the figure, the flexural rigidity, EI is
781250 kN[latex]m^{2}[/latex]. When w = 10 kN/m, the vertical reaction [latex]R_A[/latex] at A is 50 kN. The value of [latex]R_A[/latex] for w = 100 kN/m is
solution: The deflection at the free end for [latex] \begin{aligned} w(10 k N / m) &=\frac{w L^{4}}{8 E I} \\ &=\frac{10 \times(5)^{4} \times 1000}{8 \times 781250} \\ &=1 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] The gap between the beam and rigid platform is 6mm. Hence, no reaction will be developed when [latex] w=10 kN / m [/latex] Now, deflection at the free end for w( 100 kN /m ) will be [latex]=10 \times 1 \mathrm{mm}=10 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] But, this cannot be possible because margin of deflection is only 6 m. Thus w=100 kN / m will induce a reaction [latex] \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{B}} \text{ at } \mathrm{B}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \frac{w L^{4}}{8 E !}-\frac{R_{B} L^{3}}{3 E I}&=\text{ Permissible deflection}\\ \Rightarrow \frac{100 \times(5)^{4}}{8 \times 781250}&-\frac{R_{6} \times(5)^{3}}{3 \times 781250}=\frac{6}{1000} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{10}{1000}-\frac{6}{1000}&=\frac{R_{8} \times 125}{3 \times 781250} \\ \Rightarrow \quad R_{8}&=75 \mathrm{kN} \\ \therefore \quad R_{\mathrm{A}}&=(100 \times 5-75) \\ &=425 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

L is subjected to a concentrated load of magnitude P. The load can be placed

solution: When the concentrated load is placed at the midspan, maximum bending moment will develop at the mid span [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Now}\quad f&=\frac{M}{l} y \qquad\left[\because M=\frac{P L}{4}\right]\\ &=\frac{\frac{P L}{4} \times \frac{D}{2}}{\frac{B D^{3}}{12}}=\frac{3 P L}{2 B D^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 156 For linear elastic systems, the type of displacement function for the strain energy is
solution: [latex]\text { Strain Energy }=\frac{1}{2} \times \sigma \times \varepsilon=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{E} \varepsilon^{2}[/latex] Since strain is directly proportional to displacement so strain energy is directly proportional to quadratic equation of displacement.

Question 159 A simply supported beam of uniform rectangular cross-section of width b and
depth h is subjected to linear temperature gradient 0[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] at the top and T[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] at the bottom, as shown in the figure. The coefficient of linear expansion of the beam material is [latex]\alpha[/latex]. The resulting vertical deflection at the mid-span of the beam is
solution: The average change in temperature [latex]=\frac{T}{2} [/latex] The compression in the top most fibre [latex] =\alpha \times L \times \frac{T}{2}[/latex] Similarly, the elongation in bottom most fibre [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\alpha \times L \times \frac{T}{2}\\ \therefore\text{ Strain, }\varepsilon_{0}&=\frac{L \alpha T}{L \times 2}=\frac{\alpha T}{2} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore deflection at midpoint is downward. Now, from the equation of pure bending, we have [latex] \frac{M}{I}=\frac{E}{R}=\frac{f}{y}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Curvature, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{R} &=\frac{f}{E y}=\frac{\text { Strain }}{y}\left[\because y=\frac{h}{2}\right] \\ &=\frac{2 \varepsilon_{0}}{h}=\frac{\alpha T}{h} \end{aligned}[/latex] Also, from the property of circle, we have [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Deflection, }\delta&=\frac{L^{2}}{8 R}=\frac{L^{2}}{8} \times \frac{\alpha T}{h} \\ &=\frac{\alpha T L^{2}}{8 h} \text { downward } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 160 A "H" shaped frame of uniform flexural rigidity EI is loaded as shown in the
figure. The relative outward displacement between points K and O is
solution: The bending moment in the member [latex] \mathrm{JN}=\mathrm{R} \times \mathrm{h}(sagging) [/latex] [latex] \therefore\text{ Slope at J or N}=\frac{R h \times L}{2 E I} [/latex] Thus, outward displacement between points [latex] K\text{ and }O=\frac{R h L}{2 E I} \times h+\frac{R h L}{2 E I} \times h=\frac{R h^{2} L}{E I}[/latex]

question:
Question 161 A long structural column (length= L) with both ends hinged is acted upon by
an axial compressive load, P. The differential equation governing the bending of
column is given by : [latex]EI\frac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}}=-Py[/latex] Where y is the structural lateral deflection and EI is the flexural rigidity. The
first critical load on column responsible for its buckling is given by
solution: Differential equation governing the bending of column [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{E I d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}&=-P y\\ \Rightarrow \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}+\frac{P}{E I} y&=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Solution of differential equation [latex] \begin{aligned} y&=A\cos\left(x \sqrt{\frac{P}{E I}}\right)+B \sin \left(x \sqrt{\frac{P}{E I}}\right)\\ \text{when }x=0 . y&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0&=B \sin \left(L \sqrt{\frac{P}{E I}}\right) \\ \therefore \quad L \sqrt{\frac{P}{E I}}&=x\text{ (First value)}\\ \Rightarrow P&=\frac{\pi^{2} E I}{L^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex]
